revision.text: {{Blacklisted-links|1= *https://gdvaport.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/dallah-gahwa-and-the-senses_final.pdf *:''Triggered by \bfiles\.wordpress\.com\b on the global blacklist''|bot=Cyberbot II|invisible=false}} [[File:A pork, prawn and clams Cataplana.JPG|thumb|upright=1.2|Clams and shrimp in a [[cataplana]]]] This is a '''list of cooking vessels'''. A cooking vessel is a type of [[Cookware and bakeware|cookware or bakeware]] designed for cooking, baking, roasting, boiling or steaming. Cooking vessels are manufactured using materials such as steel, [[cast iron]], aluminum, [[Clay pot cooking|clay]] and various other [[ceramic]]s. Some cooking vessels, such as ceramic ones, absorb and retain heat after cooking has finished. ==Cooking vessels== [[File:Bain-marie.jpg|thumb|A [[bain-marie]] on a stovetop]] [[File:Gulyas080.jpg|thumb|Hungarian [[goulash]] in a traditional ''"bogrács"'' [[cauldron]]]] * [[Bain-marie]] or [[Double boiler]] – in cooking applications, usually consists of a pan of water in which another container or containers of food to be cooked is placed within the pan of water.{{cite book | last=Beck | first=S. | title=Simca's Cuisine | publisher=Knopf Doubleday Publishing Group | year=2013 | isbn=978-0-8041-5047-7 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=watRAQAAQBAJ&pg=PT441 | access-date=October 12, 2017 | page=441}} * [[Beanpot]] – a deep, wide-bellied, short-necked vessel used to cook bean-based dishes. Beanpots are typically made of [[ceramic]], though pots made of other materials, like cast iron, can also be found. * [[Billycan]] – a lightweight cooking pot in the form of a metal bucketBlack, S. J. S. 2010 “'Tried and Tested’: community cookbooks in Australia, 1890-1980” Thesis (Ph.D.) -- University of Adelaide, School of History and Politics{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=Ak6cBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA1364&lpg=PA1364&dq=%22billy%22+%22can%22+%22boiling%22+%22australia%22&source=bl&ots=a4P-6g2xaK&sig=rybWjBgax4iSsSuuhzG8ve1bR3U&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=%22billy%22+%22can%22+%22boiling%22+%22australia%22&f=false|title=The Concise New Partridge Dictionary of Slang and Unconventional English|first1=Tom|last1=Dalzell|first2=Terry|last2=Victor|date=27 November 2014|publisher=Routledge|accessdate=11 October 2017|via=Google Books}}Farrell, Michael. "Death Watch: Reading the Common Object of the Billycan in ‘Waltzing Matilda’." Journal of the Association for the Study of Australian Literature 10 (2010) commonly used for boiling water, making tea or cooking over a [[campfire]]{{cite web|url=http://www.nma.gov.au/exhibitions/symbols_of_australia/billy|title=Billy - National Museum of Australia|website=www.nma.gov.au|accessdate=11 October 2017}} or to carry water. * [[Bratt pan]] – large cooking receptacles designed for producing large-scale meals.{{cite book | last=Torode | first=J. | last2=Lowe | first2=J. | title=Beef: And Other Bovine Matters | publisher=Taunton Press, Incorporated | year=2009 | isbn=978-1-60085-126-1 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dc-Dab_JwH0C&pg=PA24 | access-date=October 12, 2017 | page=24}} They are typically used for [[braising]], [[searing]], shallow [[frying]] and general cooking.{{cite book | last=Foskett | first=D. | last2=Paskins | first2=P. | last3=Pennington | first3=A. | title=The Theory of Hospitality and Catering Thirteenth Edition | publisher=Hodder Education | year=2016 | isbn=978-1-4718-6494-0 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YCFeDAAAQBAJ&pg=PT259 | access-date=October 12, 2017 | page=pt259}} * [[Bread pan]] – also called a loaf pan, a pan specifically designed for baking bread.{{cite book | title=Sanitary and Heating Age | publisher=Sanitary and Heating Publishing | year=1902 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=A7bmAAAAMAAJ&pg=RA6-PA48 | access-date=October 12, 2017 | page=48}}{{cite book | title=The America's Test Kitchen Cooking School Cookbook: Everything You Need to Know to Become a Great Cook | publisher=America's Test Kitchen | year=2013 | isbn=978-1-936493-80-7 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=m4ZKCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA548 | access-date=October 12, 2017 | page=548}} * [[Caquelon]] – a cooking vessel of [[stoneware]], ceramic, [[cast iron|enamelled cast iron]], or [[porcelain]] for the preparation of [[fondue]], also called a fondue pot.{{cite book | last=Harron | first=H. | title=Not Your Mother's Fondue | publisher=Harvard Common Press | series=NYM Series | year=2010 | isbn=978-1-55832-784-9 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VQdjDAAAQBAJ&pg=PT16 | access-date=October 12, 2017 | page=16}} * [[Casserole]] – a large, deep dish used both in the oven and as a serving vessel.{{cite book | last=Rama | first=M. | last2=Miller | first2=B. | title=Cooking Basics For Dummies | publisher=Wiley | series=For dummies | year=2014 | isbn=978-1-118-92232-3 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=i9o5BAAAQBAJ&pg=PA304 | access-date=October 12, 2017 | page=304–305}} The word is also used for the food cooked and served in such a vessel, with the cookware itself called a casserole dish or casserole pan. * [[Cassole]] * [[Cassolette]] – small porcelain, glass, or metal container used for the cooking and serving of individual dishes. It can also refer to the ingredients and recipe itself. * [[Cast-iron cookware]] – typically [[Seasoning (cookware)|seasoned]] before use{{cite book | last=Rogers | first=M.R. | title=Cooking in Cast Iron: Yesterday's Flavors for Today's Kitchen | publisher=HPBooks | year=2001 | isbn=978-1-55788-367-4 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kmjgf2jZiiwC&pg=PT15 | access-date=October 12, 2017 | page=15}} * [[Cataplana]] – used to prepare Portuguese seafood dishes, popular on the country's [[Algarve]] region.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DNiSuNvBAD4C&lpg=PA11&dq=Cataplana&pg=PA11#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Portuguese Cooking: An Unforgettable Journey Through the Flavors and Colours of a Fascinating Country|location=Florence|publisher=Bonechi Books|year=2006|isbn=88-476-0921-6|page=11}} * [[Cauldron]] – a large metal pot for cooking or boiling over an open fire, with a large mouth and frequently with an arc-shaped hanger. [[Image:Chafingdish.jpg|thumb|Chafing Dish and Stand circa 1895{{cite web |publisher= [[Victoria and Albert Museum]]|url= https://collections.vam.ac.uk/item/O93019/chafing-dish-and/|title= Chafing Dish and Stand|work=Metalwork |accessdate= 2007-08-18}} Victoria and Albert Museum, London]] :* [[Ding (vessel)|Ding]] – [[prehistoric China|prehistoric]] and [[ancient China|ancient]] Chinese cauldrons, standing upon legs with a lid and two facing handles. They are one of the most important shapes used in [[Chinese ritual bronze]]s. * [[Chafing dish]] – a kind of portable grate raised on a tripod, originally heated with [[charcoal]] in a [[brazier]], and used for foods that require gentle cooking, away from the "fierce" heat of direct flames.{{cite book | last=How | first=S.B. | title=Chafing-dish dainties | publisher=E. C. Lockwood, printer | year=1898 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NlwEAAAAYAAJ | access-date=October 12, 2017}} The chafing dish could be used at table or provided with a cover for keeping food warm on a buffet. * [[Chip pan]] – a deep-sided cooking pan used for deep-frying * [[Crepulja]] – a shallow clay container with a little hole in the middle, it is put on fire until well heated, then lifted with a hook, and [[dough]] is put into it and covered with a [[sač]]. The sač is covered with ashes and live coals. * [[Crock (dishware)|Crock]] * [[Dolsot]] – a small-sized [[cookware]]-cum-[[serveware]] made of [[agalmatolite]], suitable for one to two servings of ''[[bap (food)|bap]]'' (cooked rice).{{Cite web|url=http://stdweb2.korean.go.kr/search/View.jsp?idx=87327|title=dolsot|website=[[Standard Korean Language Dictionary]]|publisher=[[National Institute of Korean Language]]|language=ko|script-title=ko:돌솥|access-date=1 March 2017}}{{Cite web|url=http://stdweb2.korean.go.kr/search/View.jsp?idx=392621|title=gopdolsot|website=[[Standard Korean Language Dictionary]]|publisher=[[National Institute of Korean Language]]|language=ko|script-title=ko:곱돌솥|access-date=1 March 2017}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.doopedia.co.kr/doopedia/master/master.do?_method=view&MAS_IDX=101013000707859|title=gopdolsot|website=[[Doopedia]]|publisher=[[Doosan Corporation]]|language=ko|script-title=ko:곱돌솥|trans-title=agalmatolite pot|access-date=1 March 2017}} In Korean cuisine, various hot rice dishes such as [[bibimbap]] or ''[[gulbap]]'' (oyster rice) as well as plain white rice can be prepared and served in ''dolsot''. As a ''dolsot'' does not cool off as soon as removed from the stove, rice continues to cook and arrives at the table still sizzling.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/wordofmouth/2013/nov/18/bibimbap-korean-dish-comfort-food|title=Bibimbap: the ultimate comfort food|last=Potter|first=Claire|date=18 November 2013|work=[[The Guardian]]|access-date=1 March 2017}} [[File:Boeuf mode.JPG|thumb|[[Beef stew]] in a [[Dutch oven]]]] * [[Dutch oven]] – a Dutch oven was originally not a cooking vessel per se, but a true oven for baking. It continued in use until the replacement of open hearth cooking by the wood-burning iron range and later gas and electric ovens. The Dutch oven or bake oven was a cast iron shallow round pot with a tight-fitting lid with a raised rim around the top. The oven was placed over live coals and live coals were placed in the lid as well. These vessels were later used for cooking stews, etc. A present day Dutch oven is used for stewing on a stove top or in a conventional oven; it is a thick-walled cooking pot with a tight-fitting lid with no raised rim.{{cite book | last=Clendenin | first=S. | last2=Child | first2=L.E. | title=New Frontiers in Dutch Oven Cooking | publisher=Horizon Publishers | year=2009 | isbn=978-0-88290-963-9 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=K_NTHS-vxD0C | access-date=October 12, 2017 }} Dutch ovens are usually made of seasoned cast iron, however some Dutch ovens are instead made of cast aluminium, or are ceramic.{{cite book | last=Griffith | first=J.B. | title=Knead It!: 35 Great Bread Recipes to Make at Home Today | publisher=Lumina Media | year=2013 | isbn=978-1-62008-054-2 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tqwKBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA71 | access-date=October 12, 2017 | page=71}}{{cite book | last=Hopkins | first=L. | title=Dutch Oven Secrets | publisher=Horizon Publishers | year=1997 | isbn=978-0-88290-372-9 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WCkj3GGw0gcC&pg=PA15 | language=de | access-date=October 12, 2017 | page=15}} * [[Fish kettle]] – a large, oval-shaped kettle used for cooking whole fish. Owing to their necessarily unwieldy size, fish kettles usually have racks and handles, and notably tight-fitting lids * [[French tian]] – an [[earthenware]] vessel of [[Provence]], France used both for cooking and serving * [[Frying pan]] – a flat-bottomed pan used for frying, searing, and browning foods :* [[Tava]] – a large flat, concave or convex disc-shaped frying pan (dripping pan) made from metal, usually sheet iron, cast iron, sheet steel or aluminium. It is used in South, Central, and West Asia, as well as in Caucasus, for cooking a variety of flatbreads and as a frying pan. * [[Gamasot]] – a big, heavy pot or cauldron used for Korean cooking{{Cite web|url=https://krdict.korean.go.kr/eng/dicSearch/SearchView?nation=eng&ParaWordNo=15374|title=gamasot|website=[[Korean-English Learners' Dictionary]]|publisher=[[National Institute of Korean Language]]|script-title=ko:가마솥|access-date=18 June 2017}}{{cite book | last=et | first=R.K. | title=Traditional Food: A Taste of Korean Life | publisher=Seoul Selection | series=Korea Essentials | year=2015 | isbn=978-1-62412-036-7 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dF6tCQAAQBAJ&pg=PT149 | access-date=October 12, 2017 | page=149}} [[File:Handi cooking vessel.jpg|thumb|A [[handi]]]] * [[Handi]] – a deep, wide-mouthed cooking vessel used in north Indian, Pakistani and Bengali cooking.{{cite book | last=Kalra | first=J.I.S. | last2=Das Gupta | first2=P. | title=Prashad: Cooking with Indian Masters | publisher=Allied Publishers Private Limited | series=First Edition | year=1986 | isbn=978-81-7023-006-9 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-UFwsluKqM8C&pg=PA27 | access-date=October 12, 2017 | page=27}} Because there are many specific Indian and Pakistani dishes cooked in this vessel, their names reflect its use, such as ''handi biryani''. * [[Karahi]] – a type of thick, circular, and deep cooking-pot similar in shape to a wok that originated in the Indian subcontinent * [[Kazan (cookware)|Kazan]] – a type of large cooking pot used throughout Central Asia, Russia, and the Balkan Peninsula * [[Marmite (cooking dish)|Marmite]] – a traditional crockery casserole vessel found in France, it is known for its "pot-belly" shape.{{cite book | last=Sinclair | first=C.G. | title=International Dictionary of Food and Cooking | publisher=Fitzroy Dearborn | year=1998 | isbn=978-1-57958-057-5 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fnveo8cyxKkC&pg=PA408 | access-date=October 12, 2017 | page=408}} * [[Mold (cooking implement)|Mold]] :* [[Muffin tin]] * [[Olla]] – a ceramic jar, often unglazed, used for cooking stews or soups, for the storage of water or dry foods, or for other purposes. * [[Pipkin]] – an [[earthenware]] cooking pot used for cooking over direct heat from coals or a wood fire * [[Palayok]] – a clay pot used as the traditional food preparation container in the Philippines used for cooking{{cite book | last=Fernandez | first=D. | last2=Best | first2=J. | title=Palayok: Philippine food through time, on site, in the pot | publisher=Bookmark | year=2000 | isbn=978-971-569-377-6 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=avuBAAAAMAAJ | access-date=October 12, 2017}}{{cite book | last=Sinclair | first=C.G. | title=International Dictionary of Food and Cooking | publisher=Fitzroy Dearborn | year=1998 | isbn=978-1-57958-057-5 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fnveo8cyxKkC&pg=PA389 | access-date=October 12, 2017 | page=389}} [[File:Si-lu (side2).jpg|thumb|A [[Bronze Age]] [[siru]] [[food steamer]]]] * [[Porringer]] – a shallow bowl, between 4 and 6 inches in diameter, and 1½" to 3" deep; the form originates in the medieval period in Europe and they were made in wood, ceramic, pewter and silver. A second, modern usage, for the term porringer is a double saucepan similar to a bain-marie used for cooking porridge. The porridge is cooked gently in the inner saucepan, heated by steam from boiling water in the outer saucepan. * [[Potjiekos|Potjie]] * [[Pressure cooking|Pressure cooker]] * [[Ramekin]] – a small glazed ceramic or glass bowl used for cooking and serving various dishes * [[Rice cooker]] * [[Roasting pan]] * [[Sinseollo#Etymology and history|Sinseollo]] – A Korean dish that shares the proper name for the cooking vessel in which this dish is served * [[Siru]] – an [[earthenware]] [[food steamer|steamer]] used to steam grain or grain flour dishes such as [[tteok|rice cake]]s.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.kr/books?id=wzJ7_WcLJSwC&pg=PA75|title=Korean Cuisine: An Illustrated History|last=Pettid|first=Michael J.|publisher=[[Reaktion Books]]|year=2008|isbn=978-1-86189-348-2|location=London|pages=75, 154}}{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.kr/books?id=nsN3BgAAQBAJ&pg=PA243|title=Encyclopedia of Korean Folk Beliefs|publisher=[[National Folk Museum of Korea]]|year=2013|isbn=9788928900572|editor-last=Chung|editor-first=Myung-sub|series=Encyclopedia of Korean Folklore and Traditional Culture|volume=II|location=Seoul|pages=243|translator-last=Jung|translator-first=Ha-yun|editor-last2=Kim|editor-first2=Tae-woo|editor-last3=Ahn|editor-first3=Hye-kyeong|editor-last4=Cho|editor-first4=Hyun-sook|editor-last5=Kim|editor-first5=Seung-yu|display-editors=1}} * [[Slow cooker]] * [[Springform pan]] – a type of bakeware that features sides that can be removed from the base{{cite book | last=Wyss | first=R. | last2=Moore | first2=K. | last3=Davick | first3=J. | title=Slow Cooker Desserts: Oh So Easy, Oh So Delicious! | publisher=St. Martin's Press | year=2015 | isbn=978-1-4668-6505-1 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=w2eWBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA6 | language=es | access-date=October 12, 2017 | page=6}} * [[Stock pot]] – a generic name for one of the most common types of cooking pot used worldwide [[File:Korean Sundubu Stew.jpg|thumb|A [[ttukbaegi]] filled with [[sundubu-jjigae]]]] * [[Sufuria]] – a flat based, deep sided, lipped and handleless cooking pot or container.{{cite book | last=Swart | first=M.F. | title=The Call of Africa: The Reformed Church in America Mission in the Sub-Sahara, 1948-1998 | publisher=Wm. B. Eerdmans | year=1998 | isbn=978-0-8028-4615-0 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zPwRjWSgzLgC&pg=PA526 | access-date=October 12, 2017 | page=526}}{{cite book | last=Harris | first=J.R. | title=Lexicographical studies in ancient Egyptian minerals | publisher=Akademie Verlag | year=1961 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wpgUAAAAIAAJ | access-date=October 12, 2017 | page=194}} It is ubiquitous in Kenya, Tanzania and other Great Lakes nations.Bailey, Richard W.; Görlach, Manfred (1982). English as a world language. University of Michigan Press. p. 317. {{ISBN|978-0-472-10016-3}} * [[Tajine]] – a North African Berber dish which is named after the earthenware pot in which it is cooked. * [[Tangia]] – an urn-shaped [[terra cotta]] cooking vessel{{cite book | last=Pawlcyn | first=C. | title=Cindy's Supper Club: Meals from Around the World to Share with Family and Friends | publisher=Potter/TenSpeed/Harmony | year=2012 | isbn=978-1-60774-207-4 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nidU2BzMLY4C&pg=PT387 | access-date=October 12, 2017 | page=pt387}} * [[Tapayan]] (or tempayan) - a large earthen jar in [[island Southeast Asia]] used for cooking, fermentation, and storing water. * [[Terrine (cookware)|Terrine]] – glazed earthenware (terracotta) cooking dish with vertical sides and a tightly fitting lid, generally rectangular or oval. Modern versions are also made of enameled cast-iron. * [[Ttukbaegi]] – a type of ''[[oji-gureut]]'',{{link language|ko}} {{Cite web|url=http://stdweb2.korean.go.kr/search/View.jsp?idx=414329|title=ttukbaegi|website=[[Standard Korean Language Dictionary]]|publisher=[[National Institute of Korean Language]]|script-title=ko:뚝배기|trans-title=stone pot|access-date=1 March 2017}} which is an ''[[onggi]]'' coated with brown-tone [[ash glaze]].{{Cite book|title=An Encyclopaedia of Korean Culture|publisher=Hansebon|year=2004|isbn=9788995135242|editor-last=Suh|editor-first=Cheong-Soo|edition=English|location=Seoul|pages=41|editor-last2=Rowan|editor-first2=Bernard|editor-last3=Cho|editor-first3=Yoon-jung}}{{Cite book|title=Korean Handicrafts: Art in Everyday Life|last=Lee|first=Jin-hyuk|last2=Mouat|first2=Colin A.|publisher=Seoul Selection|year=2014|isbn=9788997639540|location=Seoul}}{{Cite journal|last=Kim|first=Yong-ho|last2=Lee|first2=Yu jin|year=2014|title=A study on the chronology of Joseon period 'onggi' found in mid-western area.|url=http://museum.ajou.ac.kr/scp/download.asp?intdn=8&strRfile=%B0%FA%B1%E2%B0%ED%B0%ED%BF%AC%B1%B820%C8%A3_%C0%FC%C3%BC.pdf|format=PDF|journal=Archaeological Studies of Science and Technology|publisher=Ajou University Museum of Tools|volume=20|pages=109}} The small, black to brown [[earthenware]] vessel is a [[cookware]]-cum-[[serveware]] used for various ''[[jjigae]]'' (stew), ''[[gukbap]]'' (soup with rice), or other boiled dishes in Korean cuisine. As a ''ttukbaegi'' retains heat and does not cool off as soon as removed from the stove, stews and soups in ''ttukbaegi'' usually arrive at the table at a bubbling boil.{{Cite book|title=Korean Cuisine: An Illustrated History|last=Pettid|first=Michael J.|publisher=[[Reaktion Books]]|year=2008|isbn=978-1-86189-348-2|location=London|pages=57}} * [[Uruli]] * [[Wok]] – a versatile round-bottomed cooking vessel, originating from China, it is used in a range of different [[Chinese cooking techniques]] ===Coffee cooking vessels=== * [[Cezve]] – a pot designed specifically to make [[Turkish coffee]] * [[Dallah (coffee pot)|Dallah]] – a traditional Arabic coffee pot used for centuries to brew and serve Qahwa (gahwa), an [[Arabic coffee]] or Gulf coffee made through a multi-step ritual, and Khaleeji, a spicy, bitter coffee traditionally served during feasts like Eid al-Fitr.[https://gdvaport.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/dallah-gahwa-and-the-senses_final.pdf Dallah, Gahwa and the Senses] * [[Jebena]] – a container used to brew coffee in the Ethiopian and Eritrean traditional [[coffee ceremony]] File:Türk Kahvesi - Bakir Cezve.jpg|A cup of Turkish coffee, served from a copper [[cezve]], in Turkey Image:Arabic coffee.jpg|[[Dallah (coffee pot)|Dallahs]] File:Coffee_pot_at_eritrean_restaurant.jpg|An Eritrean [[jebena]] ===Steamers=== * [[Food steamer]]s are used to cook or prepare various foods with [[steam]] heat by means of holding the food in a closed vessel reducing steam escape. This manner of cooking is called [[steaming]]. :* [[Couscoussier]] – a traditional double-chambered food steamer used in Berber and Arabic cuisines (particularly, the Libyan, the Tunisian, the Algerian and the Moroccan) to cook [[couscous]].{{cite web | last=Fabricant | first=Florence | title=In the Land of Its Origin, Couscous Is More Than a Quick Fix | website=[[The New York Times]] | date=December 30, 1992 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/12/30/garden/in-the-land-of-its-origin-couscous-is-more-than-a-quick-fix.html | access-date=October 11, 2017}} :* [[Bamboo steamer]] :* [[Siru]] – an earthenware steamer used to steam grain or grain flour dishes such as ''[[tteok]]'' (rice cakes).{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.kr/books?id=wzJ7_WcLJSwC&pg=PA75|title=Korean Cuisine: An Illustrated History|last=Pettid|first=Michael J.|publisher=[[Reaktion Books]]|year=2008|isbn=978-1-86189-348-2|location=London|pages=75, 154}}{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.kr/books?id=nsN3BgAAQBAJ&pg=PA243|title=Encyclopedia of Korean Folk Beliefs|publisher=[[National Folk Museum of Korea]]|year=2013|isbn=9788928900572|editor-last=Chung|editor-first=Myung-sub|series=Encyclopedia of Korean Folklore and Traditional Culture|volume=II|location=Seoul|pages=243|translator-last=Jung|translator-first=Ha-yun|editor-last2=Kim|editor-first2=Tae-woo|editor-last3=Ahn|editor-first3=Hye-kyeong|editor-last4=Cho|editor-first4=Hyun-sook|editor-last5=Kim|editor-first5=Seung-yu|display-editors=1}} File:Dim sum steamer.jpg|[[Dim sum]] in a [[food steamer]] File:Couscoussier.jpg|A [[couscoussier]], a type of steamer used to cook [[couscous]] Image:Mushiki.Steamer.jpg|Stacked [[bamboo steamer]]s on top of a pot ==Brands and companies== * [[All-Clad]] – At the time of its founding, All-Clad used a patented "[[roll bonding]]" process in which metals are sandwiched together and then formed into a cooking vessel. The company derived its name from this cladding process, which is applied not only on the bottom but extends all the way up the sides of each cooking vessel. The company has been issued several patents by the [[United States Patent and Trademark Office]] (USPTO).{{cite news|publisher=USPTO|work= 3350772 |title=Methods of cladding stainless steel to aluminum|date= November 7, 1967|author1=Ulam, John B. |author2=Camp, William C. }} * [[Chue Chin Hua]] – an aluminium cookware and metal producing company in Thailand * [[CorningWare]] – was originally a brand name for a unique [[glass-ceramic]] ([[Pyroceram]]) [[cookware]] resistant to [[thermal shock]]. It was first introduced in 1958 by [[Corning Incorporated|Corning Glass Works]] in the United States. * [[Cousances]] – French cookware manufacturer, known for enameled cast iron pans ("cocotte" in French). The company was formed in 1553 and was acquired by Le Creuset in 1957. * [[Descoware]] – a brand of porcelain-coated cast iron cookware * [[Emile Henry (ceramic)|Emile Henry]] * [[Fire-King]] * [[Grabit (cookware)|Grabit]] – microwave-safe cookware introduced by Corning Glass Works in 1977 * [[Le Chasseur]] * [[Le Creuset]] – a French cookware manufacturer best known for its colorfully-enameled cast-iron cookware "French ovens", also known as "casseroles" or "Dutch ovens" * [[Lodge (company)|Lodge]] * [[Nordic Ware]] – a company based in Minnesota notable for introducing the [[Bundt cake]] pan in the early 1950s. *Premiere Pan (USA Pan) - Manufacturers of commercial baking pans, based in suburban [[Pittsburgh]]. * [[Pyrex]] – a brand introduced by Corning Inc. in 1908 for a line of clear, low-thermal-expansion [[borosilicate glass]] used for [[laboratory glassware]] and kitchenware. * [[Revere Ware]] – a line of consumer and commercial kitchen wares introduced in 1939 by the [[Revere Copper Company|Revere Brass & Copper Corp.]], focusing primarily on consumer cookware such as skillets, sauce pans, stock pots, and tea kettles. * [[Staub (cookware)|Staub]] – a brand of enameled cast iron cookware and bakeware that was originally headquartered in Turckheim, Alsace, France * [[Swiss Diamond International]] – a company that produces nonstick cookware using diamond crystals * [[Visions (cookware)|Visions]] – a brand of transparent stove top cookware originally created by [[Corning Inc.|Corning]] France and released in Europe during the late 1970s and in other markets beginning a short time later. * [[West Bend Company]] * [[Wonder Pot]] – an Israeli invention for baking on top of a gas stove rather than in an oven. It consists of three parts: an aluminium pot shaped like a Bundt pan except smooth-sided rather than fluted, a hooded cover perforated with venting holes, and a thick, round, slightly domed metal disc with a center hole that is placed between the pot and the flame. * [[Wonderchef]] * [[World Kitchen]] ==Gallery== Image:Lecreuset lamama-enzomari.JPG|An enameled [[Cast-iron cookware|cast-iron]] pot Image:Catawba potter.jpg|A [[Catawba (tribe)|Catawba]] potter making an [[olla]], 1908 Image:Anglit.jpg|An ''anglit'', a small [[palayok]] File:Clafoutis in ramekins, February 2009.jpg|[[Clafoutis]] in [[ramekin]]s File:Rijstkoker.jpg|An old type of [[rice cooker]] commonly used in the Netherlands by residents of the former [[Dutch East Indies]] File:Bjumbura Burundi soldiers cooking sufuria crop.jpg|Burundian soldiers cooking in a [[sufuria]] over an open fire. File:Wonder Pot cake.jpg|A brownie cake baked in a [[Wonder Pot]] ==See also== {{portal|Cooking|Food|Technology}} {{Div col|colwidth=22em}} * [[Boiling vessel]] * [[Cooker]] * [[Cousances]] * [[Fire pot]] * [[Kitchenware]] * [[List of cast-iron cookware manufacturers]] * [[List of cooking appliances]] * [[List of cooking techniques]] * [[List of food preparation utensils]] * [[Non-stick surface]] * [[Sous-vide]] * [[Thermal cooking]] {{div col end}} ==References== {{reflist|refs= {{cite book |editor-last=Acton |editor-first=Q. Ashton | title=Iron Compounds—Advances in Research and Application | publisher=Scholarly Editions | isbn=978-1-4816-8914-4 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NYz5e3fRUQ0C&pg=PA508 | date=2013 | access-date=October 11, 2017 | page=508}} {{cite book | last=Allen | first=G.J. | last2=Albala | first2=K. | title=The Business of Food: Encyclopedia of the Food and Drink Industries | publisher=Greenwood Press | year=2007 | isbn=978-0-313-33725-3 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gNzmOUyiFRAC&pg=PA106 | access-date=October 11, 2017 | page=106}} }} ==Further reading== * {{cite book | last=Allen | first=G.J. | last2=Albala | first2=K. | title=The Business of Food: Encyclopedia of the Food and Drink Industries | publisher=Greenwood Press | year=2007 | isbn=978-0-313-33725-3 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gNzmOUyiFRAC&pg=PA106 | access-date=October 11, 2017 | page=106}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cooking vessels}} [[Category:Cooking vessels| ]] [[Category:Food- and drink-related lists]] [[Category:Technology-related lists]] [[Category:Kitchenware brands]]

revision.text:
{{selfref|For assistance with IPA transcriptions of Lithuanian for Wikipedia articles, see [[Help:IPA/Lithuanian]].}} {{IPA notice}} This article is about the [[phonology]] of the [[Lithuanian language]]. Lithuanian has a phonemic inventory consisting of eleven [[vowel]]s and 45 [[consonant]]s, including 22 pairs of consonants distinguished by the presence or absence of [[Palatalization (phonetics)|palatalization]]. ==Consonants== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |+ Consonant phonemes of Lithuanian{{sfnp|Pakerys|1995|p=?}} |- ! rowspan="2" colspan="2" | ! colspan="2" | [[Labial consonant|Labial]] ! colspan="2" | [[Dental consonant|Dental]] ! colspan="2" | [[Alveolar consonant|Alveolar]] ! rowspan="2" | [[Palatal consonant|Palatal]] ! colspan="2" | [[Velar consonant|Velar]] |- style="font-size: small;" ! hard ! soft ! hard ! soft ! hard ! soft ! soft ! hard |- ! colspan="2" | [[Nasal consonant|Nasal]] | {{IPA link|m}} || {{IPA|mʲ}} | {{IPA link|n̪|n}} || {{IPA|nʲ}} | | | | | |- ! rowspan="2" | [[Stop consonant|Stop]] ! {{small|voiceless}} | {{IPA link|p}} || {{IPA|pʲ}} | {{IPA link|t̪|t}} || {{IPA|tʲ}} | | | | {{IPA|kʲ}} || {{IPA link|k}} |- ! {{small|voiced}} | {{IPA link|b}} || {{IPA|bʲ}} | {{IPA link|d̪|d}} || {{IPA|dʲ}} | | | | {{IPA|ɡʲ}} || {{IPA link|ɡ}} |- ! rowspan="2" | [[Affricate consonant|Affricate]] ! {{small|voiceless}} | colspan="2" | | {{IPA link|t̪͡s̪|t͡s}} || {{IPA|t͡sʲ}} | {{IPA link|t͡ʃ}} || {{IPA link|t͡ɕ}} | | | |- ! {{small|voiced}} | colspan="2" | | {{IPA link|d̪͡z̪|d͡z}} || {{IPA|d͡zʲ}} | {{IPA link|d͡ʒ}} || {{IPA link|d͡ʑ}} | | | |- ! rowspan="2" | [[Fricative consonant|Fricative]] ! {{small|voiceless}} | ({{IPA link|f}}) || ({{IPA|fʲ}}) | {{IPA link|s̪|s}} || {{IPA|sʲ}} | {{IPA link|ʃ}} || {{IPA link|ɕ}} | | ({{IPA|xʲ}}) || ({{IPA link|x}}) |- ! {{small|voiced}} | rowspan="2" | {{IPA|v}} || rowspan="2" | {{IPA|vʲ}} | {{IPA link|z̪|z}} || {{IPA|zʲ}} | {{IPA link|ʒ}} || {{IPA link|ʑ}} | rowspan="2" | {{IPA|j}} | ({{IPA|ɣʲ}}) || ({{IPA link|ɣ}}) |- ! colspan="2" | [[Approximant consonant|Approximant]] | {{IPA link|ɫ̪|ɫ}} | | | {{IPA link|l|lʲ}} | || |- ! colspan="2" | [[Trill consonant|Trill]] | colspan="2" | | colspan="2" | | {{IPA link|r}} || {{IPA|rʲ}} | | | |} All Lithuanian consonants except {{IPA|/j/}} have two variants: a non-[[Palatalization (phonetics)|palatalized]] one and a [[Palatalization (phonetics)|palatalized]] one, represented by the [[International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]] symbols in the chart (i.e., {{IPA|/b/}} – {{IPA|/bʲ/}}, {{IPA|/d/}} – {{IPA|/dʲ/}}, {{IPA|/ɡ/}} – {{IPA|/ɡʲ/}}, and so on). The consonants {{IPA|/f/}}, {{IPA|/x/}}, {{IPA|/ɣ/}} and their palatalized variants are only found in [[loanword]]s. Consonants preceding the front vowels {{IPA|/ɪ/}}, {{IPA|/iː/}}, {{IPA|/ɛ/}}, {{IPA|/æː/}} and {{IPA|/eː/}}, as well as any palatalized consonant or {{IPA|/j/}} are always moderately palatalized (a feature Lithuanian has in common with the [[Belarusian language|Belarusian]] and [[Russian language|Russian]] languages but which is not present in the more closely related [[Latvian language|Latvian]]). Followed by back vowels {{IPA|/aː/}}, {{IPA|/ɐ/}}, {{IPA|/oː/}}, {{IPA|/ɔ/}}, {{IPA|/uː/}}, and {{IPA|/ʊ/}}, consonants can also be palatalized (causing some vowels to shift; see the [[#Vowels|Vowels section]] below); in such cases, the standard orthography inserts the letter ''i'' between the vowel and the preceding consonant (which is not pronounced separately), e.g. ''noriu'' {{IPA|[ˈnôːrʲʊ]}}, ('I want'). Most of the non-palatalized and palatalized consonants form [[minimal pair]]s (like ''šuo'' {{IPA|[ʃuə]}}, 'dog' ~ ''šiuo'' {{IPA|[ɕuə]}}, 'with this one'), so they are independent [[phoneme]]s, rather than [[allophone]]s.Adapted from ''[[Lituanus]]'' [http://www.lituanus.org/1982_1/82_1_02.htm Lituanus.org]{{cite book|last=Ambrazas|first=Vytautas|author2=Alexas Girdenis |author3=Kazys Morkūnas |title=Lietuvių kalbos enciklopedija|publisher=Mokslo ir enciklopedijų leidybos inst|year=1999|location= Vilnius|pages=497–498|isbn=5-420-01433-5|display-authors=etal}} * All consonants are labialized before the back vowels {{IPA|/ʊ, uː, oː/}}. The hard alveolar fricatives {{IPA|/ʃ, ʒ/}} are also somewhat labialized in other{{fix|text=which?|date=February 2018}} positions.{{sfnp|Ambrazas et al.|1997|pp=36, 40}}{{fix|text=are the hard alveolar affricates {{IPA|/t͡ʃ, d͡ʒ/}} also labialized in other positions? What about the soft alveolar sibilants?|date=August 2015}} * All of the hard consonants (especially {{IPA|/ɫ, ʃ, ʒ/}}) are velarized.{{sfnp|Ambrazas et al.|1997|pp=15, 36}} * {{IPA|/n, t, d/}} are [[Laminal consonant|laminal]] [[Denti-alveolar consonant|denti-alveolar]] {{IPA|[{{IPA link|n̪}}, {{IPA link|t̪}}, {{IPA link|d̪}}]}}.{{sfnp|Augustaitis|1964|pp=15, 22}} ** {{IPA|/t, d/}} are alveolar {{IPA|[{{IPA link|t}}, {{IPA link|d}}]}} before {{IPA|/r/}}.{{sfnp|Ambrazas et al.|1997|p=41}} * {{IPA|/nʲ/}} has been variously described as palatalized laminal denti-alveolar {{IPAblink|n̪|n̪ʲ}}{{sfnp|Pakerys|1995|p=?}} and palatalized laminal alveolar {{IPAblink|n|n̻ʲ}}.{{sfnp|Augustaitis|1964|p=23}} * {{IPA|/tʲ, dʲ/}} have been variously described as: **[[Alveolo-palatal consonant|Alveolo-palatal]] {{IPA|[{{IPA link|c|c̟}}, {{IPA link|ɟ|ɟ˖}}]}}{{sfnp|Augustaitis|1964|p=16}} ** Palatalized laminal denti-alveolar {{IPA|[t̪ʲ, d̪ʲ]}} with alveolar allophones {{IPA|[tʲ, dʲ]}} before {{IPA|/rʲ/}}.{{sfnp|Ambrazas et al.|1997|pp=41, 46–47}} * Word-final {{IPA|/t, k/}} and sometimes also {{IPA|/p/}} are aspirated {{IPA|[t̪ʰ, kʰ, pʰ]}}.{{sfnp|Ambrazas et al.|1997|p=40}}{{sfnp|Mathiassen|1996|p=22}} * {{IPA|/t͡s, t͡sʲ, d͡z, d͡zʲ, s, sʲ, z, zʲ/}} are dentalized laminal [[Alveolar consonant|alveolar]] {{IPA|[{{IPA link|t̪͡s̪}}, t̪͡s̪ʲ, {{IPA link|d̪͡z̪}}, d̪͡z̪ʲ, {{IPA link|s̪}}, s̪ʲ, {{IPA link|z̪}}, z̪ʲ]}},{{sfnp|Ambrazas et al.|1997|pp=46–47}}{{sfnp|Augustaitis|1964|pp=16–18}} pronounced with the blade of the tongue very close to the upper front teeth, with the tip of the tongue resting behind lower front teeth. * {{IPA|/t͡ʃ, d͡ʒ, ʃ, ʒ/}} are laminal flat postalveolar {{IPA|[t͡ʃ˖, d͡ʒ˖, ʃ˖, ʒ˖]}}, i.e. they are pronounced without any palatalization at all.{{sfnp|Augustaitis|1964|pp=20–22}}The transcription {{IPA|[t͡ʃ˖, d͡ʒ˖, ʃ˖, ʒ˖]}} follows {{Harvcoltxt|Laver|1994|pp=251–252}}. Other scholars may transcribe these sounds differently. * {{IPA|/t͡ɕ, d͡ʑ, ɕ, ʑ/}} are alveolo-palatal {{IPA|[{{IPA link|t͡ɕ}}, {{IPA link|d͡ʑ}}, {{IPA link|ɕ}}, {{IPA link|ʑ}}]}}.{{sfnp|Augustaitis|1964|pp=20–22}} Traditionally, they are transcribed with {{angbr|{{IPA|t͡ʃʲ, d͡ʒʲ, ʃʲ, ʒʲ}}}}, but these symbols can be seen as equivalent to {{angbr|{{IPA|t͡ɕ, d͡ʑ, ɕ, ʑ}}}}, which is a less complex transcription.{{sfnp|Ladefoged|Maddieson|1996|p=?}} * {{IPA|/v, vʲ/}} have been variously described as fricatives {{IPA|[{{IPA link|v}}, {{IPA link|v|vʲ}}]}}{{sfnp|Ambrazas et al.|1997|pp=46–47}}{{sfnp|Augustaitis|1964|pp=13–14}} and approximants {{IPA|[{{IPA link|ʋ}}, {{IPA link|ʋ}}ʲ]}}.{{sfnp|Mathiassen|1996|pp=22–23}} * {{IPA|/ɫ/}} is laminal denti-alveolar {{IPAblink|ɫ̪}}.{{sfnp|Ambrazas et al.|1997|pp=36, 46–47}}{{sfnp|Mathiassen|1996|p=23}}{{sfnp|Augustaitis|1964|p=19}} * {{IPA|/lʲ/}} has been variously described as palatalized alveolar {{IPA|[lʲ]}}{{sfnp|Pakerys|1995|p=?}} and palatalized laminal denti-alveolar {{IPA|[l̪ʲ]}}.{{sfnp|Ambrazas et al.|1997|pp=36, 46–47}}{{sfnp|Mathiassen|1996|p=23}}{{sfnp|Augustaitis|1964|pp=18–19}} * {{IPA|/j/}} has been variously described as an approximant {{IPAblink|j}}{{sfnp|Mathiassen|1996|pp=22–23}} and a fricative {{IPAblink|ʝ}}.{{sfnp|Augustaitis|1964|p=23}}{{sfnp|Ambrazas et al.|1997|pp=46–47}} * {{IPA|/r, rʲ/}} are [[apical consonant|apical]] alveolar {{IPA|[{{IPA link|r|r̺}}, r̺ʲ]}}.{{sfnp|Ambrazas et al.|1997|pp=46–47}}{{sfnp|Augustaitis|1964|pp=19–20}} * Before {{IPA|/k, ɡ/}}, {{IPA|/n/}} is realized as velar {{IPAblink|ŋ}}. Likewise, before {{IPA|/kʲ, ɡʲ/}}, {{IPA|/nʲ/}} is realized as {{IPA|[ŋʲ]}}.{{sfnp|Ambrazas et al.|1997|p=40}}Girdenis, Aleksas.''Teoriniai lietuvių fonologijos pagrindai'' (''The theoretical basics of the phonology of Lithuanian'', in Lithuanian), 2nd Edition, Vilnius: Mokslo ir enciklopedijų leidybos inst., 2003. pp. 68–72. {{ISBN|5-420-01501-3}} * {{IPA|/ɣ/}} is sometimes realized as {{IPAblink|ɦ}}. Since the palatalized variant is always velar {{IPA|[ɣʲ]}}, {{IPA|[ɣ]}} is preferred over {{IPA|[ɦ]}}.A. Pakerys. "Bendrinės lietuvių kalbos fonetika" Vilnius, 1995 * In the case of the soft velar consonants {{IPA|/kʲ, ɡʲ, xʲ, ɣʲ/}} (as well as the {{IPA|[ŋʲ]}} allophone of {{IPA|/n/}}), the softness (palatalization) is realized as slight fronting of the place of articulation to [[post-palatal]] {{IPA|[{{IPA link|k̟}}, {{IPA link|ɡ˖}}, {{IPA link|x̟}}, {{IPA link|ɣ˖}}, {{IPA link|ŋ˖}}]}}.{{sfnp|Mathiassen|1996|pp=22–23}}{{sfnp|Ambrazas et al.|1997|p=36}} However, according to {{Harvcoltxt|Augustaitis|1964}}, the stops {{IPA|/kʲ, ɡʲ/}} are more strongly advanced, i.e. to palatal {{IPA|[{{IPA link|c}}, {{IPA link|ɟ}}]}}, rather than post-palatal {{IPA|[{{IPA link|k̟}}, {{IPA link|ɡ˖}}]}}.{{sfnp|Augustaitis|1964|pp=24–25}} * [[Plosive]]s have [[no audible release]] before other plosives. ==Vowels== Lithuanian has six long vowels and five short ones (not including the disputed {{IPA|/e/}}). Length has traditionally been considered the distinctive feature, though short vowels are also more centralized and long vowels more peripheral: {| class="wikitable" |- ! ! colspan=2|[[Front vowel|Front]] ! colspan=2|[[Central vowel|Central]] ! colspan=2|[[Back vowel|Back]] |- align=center ![[Close vowel|Close]] | {{IPA link|iː}} || {{IPA link|ɪ}} || colspan=2| || {{IPA link|ʊ}} || {{IPA link|uː}} |- align=center ![[Mid vowel|Mid]] | {{IPA link|eː}} || {{IPA link|ɛ}}, ({{IPA link|e}}) || colspan=2| || ({{IPA link|ɔ}}) || {{IPA link|oː}} |- align=center ![[Open vowel|Open]] | {{IPA link|æː}} || || {{IPA link|ɐ}} || {{IPA link|ä|aː}} || colspan=2| |} * {{IPA|/e, ɔ/}} are restricted to loanwords. Many speakers merge the former with {{IPA|/ɛ/}}.{{sfnp|Ambrazas et al.|1997|p=24}} * {{IPA|/ɐ, aː/}} are phonetically central {{IPA|[{{IPA link|ɐ}}, {{IPA link|äː}}]}}. Phonologically, they behave like back vowels. In standard Lithuanian vowels {{IPA|[aː]}} and {{IPA|[ɐ]}} generally are not pronounced after any palatalized consonant (including {{IPA|[j]}}). In this position, they systematically shift to {{IPA|[æː]}} or {{IPA|[ɛː]}} and {{IPA|[ɛ]}} respectively: ''galia'' ('power') = ''gale'' ('in the end') {{IPA|[ɡɐˈlʲɛ]}}, ''gilią'' ('profound' singular accusative) = ''gilę'' ('acorn' singular accusative) {{IPA|[ˈɡʲɪlʲæː]}}. On the other hand, in everyday language {{IPA|[ɛː]}} usually shifts to {{IPA|[æː]}} (or sometimes even {{IPA|[aː]}}) if the vowel precedes a non-palatalized consonant: ''jachtą,'' ('yacht' singular accusative), or ''retas,'' ('rare'), are often realized as {{IPA|[ˈjæːxtaː]}} and {{IPA|[ˈrʲæːtɐs]}} (or sometimes even {{IPA|[ˈjaːxtaː]}} and {{IPA|[ˈrʲaːtɐs]}}) instead of {{IPA|[ˈjɛːxtaː]}} and {{IPA|[ˈrʲɛːtɐs]}} as the following consonants {{IPA|/x/}} and {{IPA|/t/}} are not palatalized.Dabartinės lietuvių kalbos gramatika. Vilnius, 1997, page 23, §14(2) This phenomenon does not affect short vowels. ===Diphthongs=== Lithuanian is traditionally described as having nine [[diphthong]]s, ''ai'','' au'','' ei'','' eu'','' oi'','' ou'','' ui'','' ie'', and'' uo.'' However, some approaches (i.e., Schmalstieg 1982) treat them as vowel sequences rather than diphthongs; indeed, the longer component depends on the type of stress, whereas in diphthongs, the longer segment is fixed. Lithuanian long stressed syllables can have either a rising or a falling tone. In specialized literature, they are marked with a tilde {{angbr|˜}} or an acute accent {{angbr|´}} respectively. The tone is especially clearly audible in diphthongs, since in the case of the rising tone, it makes the second element longer (e.g., ''aĩ'' is pronounced {{IPA|[ɐɪ̯ˑ]}}), while the falling tone prolongs the first element (e.g., ''ái'' is pronounced {{IPA|[âˑɪ̯]}}) (for more detailed information, see [[Lithuanian accentuation]]). The full set is as follows: {|class=wikitable |- ! !! stressless
or tilde !! acute stress |- align=center ! ai |{{IPA|ɐɪ̯ˑ}} || {{IPA|âˑɪ̯}} |- align=center ! ei | {{IPA|ɛɪ̯ˑ}} || {{IPA|æ̂ˑɪ̯}} |- align=center ! au | {{IPA|ɐʊ̯ˑ}} || {{IPA|âˑʊ̯}} |- align=center ! eu | {{IPA|ɛʊ̯ˑ}} || {{IPA|ɛ̂ʊ̯}} |- align=center ! iau | {{IPA|ɛʊ̯ˑ}} || {{IPA|æ̂ˑʊ̯}} |- align=center !{{Not a typo|ie}} |{{IPA|iə}} ||{{IPA|îə}}[http://www.baltistica.lt/index.php/baltistica/article/view/1313/1231 Vadinamųjų sutaptinių dvibalsių [ie uo] garsinė ir fonologinė sudėtis | Girdenis | Baltistica] |- align=center ! oi |– || {{IPA|ɔ̂ɪ̯}} |- align=center ! ou |– || {{IPA|ɔ̂ʊ̯}} |- align=center ! ui |{{IPA|ʊɪ̯ˑ}} || {{IPA|ʊ̂ɪ̯}} |- align=center ! uo | {{IPA|uə}} || {{IPA|ûə}} |} ==Pitch accent== {{Main|Lithuanian accentuation}} The Lithuanian prosodic system is characterized by free accent and distinctive quantity. Its accentuation is sometimes described as a simple [[tone (linguistics)|tone]] system, often called [[pitch accent]].''Phonetic invariance and phonological stability: Lithuanian pitch accents'' Grzegorz Dogil & Gregor Möhler, 1998 [http://eprints.kfupm.edu.sa/57901/]{{dead link|date=February 2014}} In [[lexical word]]s, one syllable will be tonically prominent. A [[heavy syllable]]—that is, a syllable containing a [[long vowel]], [[diphthong]], or a [[sonorant]] coda—may have one of two tones, ''falling tone'' (or ''acute tone'') or ''rising tone'' (or ''circumflex tone''). Light syllables (syllables with short vowels and optionally also [[obstruent]] codas) do not have the two-way contrast of heavy syllables. Common Lithuanian lexicographical practice uses three diacritic marks to indicate word accent, i.e., the tone and quantity of the accented syllable. They are used in the following way: * The first (or the only) segment of a heavy syllable with a falling tone is indicated with an acute accent mark (e.g., ''á'', ''ár''), unless the first element is ''i'' or ''u'' followed by a [[tautosyllabic]] resonant, in which case it is marked with a grave accent mark (e.g., ''ìr'', ''ùr''). * The second (or the only) segment of a heavy syllable with a rising tone is indicated with a circumflex accent (e.g., ''ã'', ''ar̃'') * Short accented syllables are indicated with a grave accent mark (e.g., ''ì'', ''ù''). As said, Lithuanian has a ''free'' accent, which means that its position and type is not phonologically predictable and has to be learned by heart. This is the state of affairs inherited from [[Proto-Balto-Slavic language|Proto-Balto-Slavic]] and, to a lesser extent, from [[Proto-Indo-European language|Proto-Indo-European]]; Lithuanian circumflex and acute syllables directly reflect Proto-Balto-Slavic acute and circumflex tone opposition. In a word-final position, the tonal distinction in heavy syllables is almost neutralized, with a few minimal pairs remaining such as ''šáuk,'' ('shoot!'), vs. ''šaũk,'' ('shout!)'. In other syllables, the two-way contrast can be illustrated with pairs such as: ''kóšė'' ('porridge') vs. ''kõšė'' ('it soured'); ''áušti'' ('to cool') vs. ''aũšti'' ('to dawn'); ''drímba'' ('lout') vs. ''drim̃ba'' ('it falls'); ''káltas'' ('chisel') vs. ''kal̃tas'' ('guilty'), ''týrė'' ('[he/she] explored') vs. ''tỹrė'' ('mush'). ''Kóšė'' is perceived as having a falling pitch ({{IPA|/ˈkôːɕeː/}} or {{IPA|/ˈkóòɕeː/}}), and indeed acoustic measurement strongly supports this. However, while ''kõšė'' is perceived as having a rising pitch ({{IPA|[ˈkǒːɕeː]}} or {{IPA|[ˈkòóɕeː]}}), this is not supported acoustically; measurements do not find a consistent tone associated with such syllables that distinguish them from unaccented heavy syllables. The distinguishing feature appears to be a negative one, that they do not have a falling tone. If diphthongs (and truly long vowels) are treated as sequences of vowels, then a single stress mark is sufficient for transcription: ''áušta'' {{IPA|/ˈauʃta/}} > {{IPA|[ˈâˑʊʃtɐ]}} ('it cools') vs. ''aũšta'' {{IPA|/aˈuʃta/}} > {{IPA|[ɐˈuˑʃtɐ]}} ('it dawns'); ''kóšė'' {{IPA|/ˈkooɕe/}} > {{IPA|[ˈkôːɕeː]}} ('porridge') vs. ''kõšė'' {{IPA|/koˈoɕe/}} > {{IPA|[koˈoˑɕeː]}} ('it soured'). The Lithuanian accentual system inherited another very important aspect from the Proto-Balto-Slavic period, and that is the [[Proto-Balto-Slavic#Balto-Slavic fixed and mobile paradigms|accentual mobility]]. Accents can alternate throughout the inflection of a word by both the syllable position and type. Parallels can be drawn with some modern Slavic languages, namely [[Russian language|Russian]], [[Serbo-Croatian language|Serbo-Croatian]] and [[Slovene language|Slovene]]. Accentual mobility is prominent in nominal stems, while verbal stems mostly demonstrate phonologically predictable patterns. Lithuanian nominal stems are commonly divided into four accentual classes, usually referred to by their numbers: * Accent paradigm 1: Fixed (columnar) accent on a non-[[desinence|desinential]] syllable. If the accent is on a pre-desinential syllable, it carries the acute tone. * Accent paradigm 2: Alternation of accent on a short or circumflex pre-desinential syllable with desinential accentuation. * Accent paradigm 3: Alternation of accent on a non-desinential syllable with desinential accentuation. If the accent is on a pre-desinential syllable, it carries the acute tone. * Accent paradigm 4: Alternation of accent on short or circumflex pre-desinential syllable with desinential accentuation. {| class="wikitable" |- ! [[Grammatical number|number]] ! [[Grammatical case|case]] ! Accent paradigm 1 ! Accent paradigm 2 ! Accent paradigm 3 ! Accent paradigm 4 |- | rowspan=7 | [[grammatical number|sg]] | [[nominative case|N]] | [[wikt:vyras#Lithuanian|výras]] | [[wikt:ranka#Lithuanian|rankà]] | [[wikt:galva#Lithuanian|galvà]] | [[wikt:dievas#Lithuanian|diẽvas]] |- | [[vocative case|V]] | výre | rañka | gálva | diẽve |- | [[accusative case|A]] | výrą | rañką | gálvą | diẽvą |- | [[genitive case|G]] | výro | rañkos | galvõs | diẽvo |- | [[dative case|D]] | výrui | rañkai | gálvai | diẽvui |- | [[locative case|L]] | výre | rañkoje | galvojè | dievè |- | [[instrumental case|I]] | výru | rankà | gálva | dievù |- | rowspan=6 | [[grammatical number|pl]] | [[nominative case|N]][[vocative case|V]] | výrai | rañkos | gálvos | dievaĩ |- | [[accusative case|A]] | výrus | rankàs | gálvas | dievùs |- | [[genitive case|G]] | výrų | rañkų | galvų̃ | dievų̃ |- | [[dative case|D]] | výrams | rañkoms | galvóms | dieváms |- | [[locative case|L]] | výruose | rañkose | galvosè | dievuosè |- | [[instrumental case|I]] | výrais | rañkomis | galvomìs | dievaĩs |} The previously described accentual system primarily applies to the Western [[Aukštaitian dialect]] on which the standard Lithuanian literary language is based. The speakers of the other group of Lithuanian dialects – [[Samogitian dialect|Samogitian]] – have a very different accentual system, and they do not adopt standard accentuation when speaking the standard idiom. Speakers of the major cities, such as [[Vilnius]], [[Kaunas]] and [[Klaipėda]], with mixed populations generally do not have intonational oppositions in spoken language, even when they speak the standard idiom. ==Change and variation== The [[sound change|changes]] and variation in Lithuanian [[Indo-European sound laws#Consonants|phonetics]] include diachronic changes of a quality of a [[phoneme]], [[alternation (linguistics)|alternations]], dialectal variation, variation between corresponding sounds of individual inflectional [[morpheme]]s of the same [[grammatical category]], which is at the same time qualitative and quantitative, diachronic and synchronic. *The diachronic qualitative phonemic changes include o {{IPA|/oː/}} ← ā (a narrowing of a more open vowel), uo ← ō turnings. *Among examples of the variation between sounds of different inflectional [[morpheme]]s of a certain [[grammatical category]] there is historical shortening of a [[Lithuanian declension|declensional ending]] ''a'' in some positions: ''motina'' ('mother' nom. sg.-instr. sg.) < *mātina < *mātinā, *mātinās > motinos (gen. sg.). Synchronous variation between shorter (more recent) and longer (more archaic) personal endings in [[Lithuanian grammar#The Verb|verbs]], depending on final position: keli'''u''' ('I am lifting something')' – keli'''uo'''si ('I am getting up' reflexive); kel'''i''' ('you are lifting')  – kel'''{{notatypo|ie}}'''si ('you get up'); kelia'''me''' ('we are lifting) ' – kelia'''mė'''s ('we get up'). *Examples of [[alternation (linguistics)|alternation]] include variation between {{IPA|/d, t/}} and palatalized {{IPA|/d͡ʑ t͡ɕ/}} respectively: nom. sg. pa'''t'''-s 'myself; himself; itself' (''masculine gender''), gen. sg. pa'''t'''-ies, dat. sg. pa'''č'''-iam; jau'''č'''iu 'I feel', jau'''t'''i 'you feel'; gir'''dž'''iu 'I hear', gir'''d'''i 'you hear'. Variation between a lengthened, uttered in a falling, lengthened tone and a short ''a'' and ''e'' alike (only if these sounds end a syllable), variation between a long, uttered in a falling, lengthened tone and a short ''i'' at an ending of a word, depending on accentual position: v'''ã'''karas {{IPA|[ˈvaːkɐrɐs]}} ''nominative'' 'an evening', v'''a'''karè {{IPA|[vɐkɐˈrɛ]}} ''locative'' 'in the evening'; radinỹs {{IPA|[rɐdɪˈniːs]}} ''nom.'' 'a finding, a find', rãdinio {{IPA|[ˈraːdɪnʲoː]}} ''genitive'' (from ràsti {{IPA|[ˈrɐstɪ]}} 'to find'); pãtiekalas 'a dish, course', patiekalaĩ ''nom. plural.'' (from patiẽkti 'to serve (a dish)'); vèsti 'to lead; to marry' vedìmas (a noun for an action) vẽdamas (participle) 'who is being led; married'; baltinỹs 'cloth which is being whitened', baltìnis 'white; (dial.) white of the egg' (derivatives from baltas 'white'). a beverage || || || to drink |- | durti || duriu || dūriau || dūrimas || || || || to prickle, job |- valign=top | vyti || veju || vijau || vijimas || || vytis [[Coat of arms of Lithuania|a chaser]]
pavojus a danger, alert || || to chase; to strand, wind |- | visti || vysta (III p.) || viso (III p.) || visimas || || || visas all, entire || to breed (for oneself) |- valign=top | veisti || veisiu || veisiau || veisimas || || vaisius a fruit
vaistas a drug || || to rear, to breed (something) |- | vysti || vysta (III p.) || vyto (III p.) || vytimas || || || || to fade, wither, languish |} The examples in the table are given as an overview, the word formation comprises many words not given here, for example, any verb can have an adjective made by the same pattern: sverti – svarus 'valid; ponderous'; svirti – svarùs 'slopable'; vyti – vajùs 'for whom it is characteristic to chase or to be chased'; pilti – pilùs 'poury'; but for example visti – vislùs 'prolific' (not visus, which could conflict with an adjective of a similar form visas 'all, entire'). Many verbs, besides a noun derivative with the ending -ìmas, can have different derivatives of the same meaning: pilti – pylìmas, pylà, pỹlis (they mean the act of the verb: a pouring (of any non solid material)); the first two have meanings that look almost identical but are drawn apart from a direct link with the verb: pylimas 'a bank, an embankment', pylà 'pelting; spanking, whipping'; the word svõris 'a weight', for example, does not have the meaning of an act of weighing. There are also many other derivatives and patterns of derivation. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Bibliography== {{Refbegin}} * {{Citation |last1=Ambrazas |first1=Vytautas |last2=Geniušienė |first2=Emma |last3=Girdenis |first3=Aleksas |last4=Sližienė |first4=Nijolė |last5=Valeckienė |first5=Adelė |last6=Valiulytė |first6=Elena |last7=Tekorienė |first7=Dalija |last8=Pažūsis |first8=Lionginas |year=1997 |editor-last=Ambrazas |editor-first=Vytautas |title=Lithuanian Grammar |publisher=Institute of the Lithuanian Language |place=Vilnius |isbn=9986-813-22-0 |ref={{harvid|Ambrazas et al.|1997}} }} * {{Citation |last=Augustaitis |first=Daine |year=1964 |title=Das litauische Phonationssystem |place=Munich |publisher=Sagner |url=http://digi20.digitale-sammlungen.de/de/fs2/object/display/bsb00046700_00001.html?sort=sortTitle+asc&subjectRVK={Slawistik}&context=&person_str={Augustaitis%2C+Daine}&LOC_ent={Germany}&mode=simple }} * {{SOWL}} * {{Citation |last=Laver |first=John |title=Principles of Phonetics |location=Cambridge |publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=1994 |isbn=0-521-45655-X }} * {{Citation |last=Mathiassen |first=Terje |year=1996 |title=A Short Grammar of Lithuanian |publisher=Slavica Publishers, Inc. |isbn=978-0893572679 }} {{Refend}} {{Language phonologies}} [[Category:Lithuanian language]] [[Category:Language phonologies]]

page.title: Midnight Patrol: Adventures in the Dream Zone

revision.text:
{{More citations needed|date=October 2010}} {{Infobox television | show_name = Midnight Patrol: Adventures in the Dream Zone | image = | caption = | show_name_2 = | genre = [[Animation]]

'''Aniamation Directors:'''
[[Robert Alvarez]] | creative_director = [[Ray Patterson (animator)|Ray Patterson]] | presenter = | starring = | judges = | voices = [[Michael Bell (actor)|Michael Bell]]

[[Clive Revill]]
[[Frank Welker]] | narrated = | theme_music_composer = [[Michael Tavera]] | composer = | country = United States
United Kingdom | language = English | num_seasons = | num_episodes = 13 | list_episodes = | executive_producer = [[William Hanna]]
[[Joseph Barbera]]
Martin Powell
Vivien Schrager-Powell
Paul Sabella | producer = [[Davis Doi]] | editor = | location = | cinematography = | camera = | runtime = 21 mins | company = [[Hanna-Barbera|Hanna-Barbera Productions]]
[[Entertainment Rights|Sleepy Kids PLC]] | distributor = Great American Broadcasting (original)
[[NBCUniversal Television Distribution]] (currently) | channel = [[BBC]]
[[The Children's Channel]] (UK)
[[Broadcast syndication|Syndication]] (US) | picture_format = | audio_format = | first_run = | first_aired = September 1, 1990 | last_aired = November 24, 1990 | preceded_by = | followed_by = | related = | website = | production_website = }} '''''Midnight Patrol: Adventures in the Dream Zone''''' is a British American animated series produced by [[Hanna-Barbera]] in conjunction with [[Entertainment Rights|Sleepy Kids PLC]] and is known outside the US as '''''Potsworth & Co.'''''. In the United Kingdom (which is reflected in the theme song's lyrics in the British broadcast), the BBC felt that the suggestion of children being awake after midnight was inappropriate, thus the name was changed. ==History== The series revolves around Potsworth, an [[English Springer Spaniel]], based upon a real-life springer spaniel called Potsworth, bought from the [[Battersea Dogs and Cats Home|Battersea Dogs Home]] by Martin and Vivien Schrager-Powell. The couple were somewhat disheartened with some of the children's programmes being made at the time, commenting that "Six-year-olds just aren't content to be fobbed off with 'Mr Wizard go pouf and nasty man go away'. Stories these days have to be believable, contain some logical process". In 1987, Martin started writing stories about Potsworth who lives in a city in America and four young children: Carter, Keiko, Rosie, and Nick. The couple took the idea to [[Hanna-Barbera]] and suggested a 50-50 deal to turn the stories into a television series.{{cite web|url=http://www.managementtoday.co.uk/news/409470/UK-Making-Tough-Tots---SLEEPY-KIDS/?DCMP=ILC-SEARCH |title=UK: Making it Tough for Tots - SLEEPY KIDS. |publisher=Management Today |date=1992-06-01 |accessdate=2012-09-15}} First appearing on ''[[The Funtastic World of Hanna-Barbera]]'' on the 1st September [[1990 in television|1990]], ''Midnight Patrol: Adventures in the Dream Zone'' lasted only 13 episodes. It was watched by 8.5 million in the US while 5.1 million watched the series on [[CBBC]] in Britain, making it the "second most popular children's show on British television after ''[[Neighbours]]''". The "real" Potsworth became something of a celebrity when he featured extensively in the British media as part of the promotion campaign for the cartoon series when it first aired in the UK in 1990/91 television season. A comic strip based on the show featured in the merged ''[[The Beezer|Beezer and Topper]]'' and, when that comic closed, the ''[[The Dandy|Dandy]]''. The series' setting, "Dream Zone", was first used on "Back to Next Saturday", the NBC Saturday Morning preview special for the 1985 season. ==Premise== The series tells of four children and Potsworth the dog who live in the same neighborhood. When they go to sleep at night they turn up in the Dream Zone where, as the Midnight Patrol, they are appointed by the Grand Dozer to protect it from nightmares and other threats and are given their missions by the Snooze Patrol. Their main enemy is the Nightmare Prince. Whilst they are in the Dream Zone, the five have special powers. Keiko has a flying [[skateboard]]; Carter can draw anything and then have it come to life; Nick is super-strong and is able to fly; his stuffed toy Murphy comes to life; whilst his cynical sister Rosie tags along. Potsworth himself acquires the power of speech which enables him to complain about the way he is treated in the real world, and make wry comments about the kids and their own attitudes and relationships. The cartoon Potsworth had a very "English" accent, even in the American version of the programmes, reflecting his real-life counterpart's British origins. ==Computer game== An officially licensed computer game of the series, using its British title of ''Potsworth and Co'', was released in 1992 by Hi-Tec Software for the [[ZX Spectrum]], [[Amstrad CPC]], [[Commodore 64]] and [[Atari ST]]. In this scrolling [[platform game]], the player took on the role of one of the characters in each themed level and had to collect various items and then reach the exit. ==Characters== ===Midnight Patrol=== The 5 Midnight Patrol members are the main stars of the show. Each one has his/her individual abilities. * '''Potsworth''' - A sarcastic 10-year-old [[English Springer Spaniel]] who usually has a stern voice when he enters the Dream Zone. * '''Nick''' - A 6-year-old boy who is a flying superhero when he's in the Dream Zone and is sometimes referred to as "Super Nick". ** '''Murphy''' - Nick's toy [[Brontosaurus]] who comes to life when he enters the Dream Zone. * '''Rosie''' - Nick's 8-year old big sister. An annoying brat who gives the group a very hard time (in ways similar to [[Lucy van Pelt]] in the ''[[Peanuts]]'' comics by Charles M. Schulz, Margaret Wade in the ''[[Dennis the Menace (U.S. comics)|Dennis the Menace]]'' comics by Hank Ketcham, Zoe in H-B's ''[[Fantastic Max]]'' cartoon series or [[Angelica Pickles]] in Nickelodeon's ''[[Rugrats]]'' cartoon series), though she still helps out in dangerous situations. She calls Nick by his full name "Nicholas" whenever she yells at him, which is quite often. She is the only member of the Midnight Patrol without a special ability. * '''Keiko''' - A 9-year-old [[Asian Americans|Asian American]] girl who rides a flying skateboard. She is energetic and very optimistic and likes to be seen as the leader of the group. * '''Carter''' - A 10-year old [[African Americans|African American]] boy who is an expert artist. In the Dream Zone his magic paintbrush can bring many things to life. He is Potsworth's owner. ===Other Dream Zone characters=== The Dream Zone has a number of inhabitants, the principals of which include: * '''The Grand Dozer''' - King of the Dream Zone, he spends his time half-asleep on top of a pile of mattresses. He has to stay this way because if he were to be fully awake the Dream Zone will come to an end. He gives advice but in the form of riddles which can be a bit of a frustration. * '''The Chief''' - A large but friendly woman who heads the local police and assigns the Midnight Patrol with their missions. * '''Sebastian''' - The Grand Dozer's head butler. He is always anxious that his King is safe and asleep. A running gag of the series is that, whenever Sebastian claims the Grand Dozer is in a certain mood, the Grand Dozer would be shown sleeping, prompting Sebastian to state the Grand Dozer would be in that mood if he were awake. * '''The Greystone Giant''' - A giant made of rock who lives in a cave filled with various objects which he supplies for people's dreams. Because there are so many dreamers he is always at work and never stops grumbling about it, though deep down he loves his job. ===Antagonists=== * '''The Nightmare Prince''' - The villain of the series. The Nightmare Prince is always coming up with ways of disrupting the Grand Dozer's sleep or other nasty schemes in order to allow nightmares to take over from dreams. He is the Midnight Patrol's main enemy, though he is such a bungling idiot that his plans can fail due to his own incompetence. ** '''Igor''' - One of the Nightmare Prince's dimwitted potato-shaped minions. ** '''Irving''' - One of the Nightmare Prince's dimwitted potato-shaped minions. ** '''Shorty''' - One of the Nightmare Prince's dimwitted potato-shaped minions. * '''The Nightmare Prince's Mother''' - This [[unseen character]] is always phoning up to tell her son to get on with destroying happy dreams, and reproving him when things go wrong. The fact that the Prince has a large-sized telephone (as opposed to a [[mobile phone]]) literally up his sleeve means that she calls him almost all the time. Her constant yapping through the phone is reminiscent of the General from ''[[Dastardly and Muttley in Their Flying Machines]]''. ===Other villains=== * '''The Nosey Bird''' - A villain that talks creeky like [[Peter Lorre]] and only appears in ''The Nightmirror'' and ''Santanapped'' where he promises the Nightmare Prince not to tell anyone his secret. The Nightmare Prince was actually hoping he'd gossip. * '''Count Bubba Bonebreaker''' - The nephew of the Nightmare Prince's Mother and the cousin of the Nightmare Prince. This villain was once in charge of nightmares when the Nightmare Prince's Mother demoted him to janitor. ==Episode guide== {| class="wikitable" style="width:90%; background:#FFFFFF" |- style="color:#FFFFFF" ! style="background:#0000A0; width:20px"| Nº ! style="background:#0000A0"| Title ! style="background:#0000A0; width:130px"| Original air date {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 1 | Title = Night of the BedBugs | OriginalAirDate = {{start date|1990|9|1|df=y}} | ShortSummary = The Nightmare Prince accidentally unleashes a horde of creatures called BedBugs and needs the Midnight Patrol's help to get rid of them. | LineColor = 0000A0 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 2 | Title = The Dozer Walks Among Us | OriginalAirDate = {{start date|1990|9|8|df=y}} | ShortSummary = When he [[Sleepwalking|sleepwalk]]s, the Grand Dozer goes around the Dream Zone causing unintentional chaos and destruction. Thus, he has to be locked up once in a while in order to prevent this — that is, until the Nightmare Prince lets him loose. | LineColor = 0000A0 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 3 | Title = King Potsworth | OriginalAirDate = {{start date|1990|9|15|df=y}} | ShortSummary = Potsworth becomes the somewhat reluctant king of a kingdom of dogs, under threat by a giant, devastating cat. | LineColor = 0000A0 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 4 | Title = The Nightmirror | OriginalAirDate = {{start date|1990|9|22|df=y}} | ShortSummary = The Nightmare Prince steals the Nightmirror which he uses to create evil twins of the Midnight Patrol who wreak havoc in the Dream Zone. | LineColor = 0000A0 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 5 | Title = When Bubba Rules | OriginalAirDate = {{start date|1990|9|29|df=y}} | ShortSummary = Exasperated by her son's constant failures to destroy the Dream Zone, the Nightmare Prince's mother assigns her monstrous nephew Count Bubba Bonebreaker to act as his supervisor. Though Count Bonebreaker takes over his job and demotes him to janitor. Before long, the Midnight Patrol decide that the Prince was not such a bad thing after all. | LineColor = 0000A0 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 6 | Title = Nick's Super Switch | OriginalAirDate = {{start date|1990|10|6|df=y}} | ShortSummary = Super Nick switches abilities with the powers of Wonder Kid after he has read many of his Wonder Kid comic books. | LineColor = 0000A0 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 7 | Title = Dozer Quest | OriginalAirDate = {{start date|1990|10|13|df=y}} | ShortSummary = The Grand Dozer is not sleeping and if he stays awake, the Dream Zone will end. The Midnight Patrol have to go to all lengths to get him back to sleep. Carter has an idea, but then he can't sleep either. | LineColor = 0000A0 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 8 | Title = Rosie's Extra Sweet Day | OriginalAirDate = {{start date|1990|10|20|df=y}} | ShortSummary = After a conversation with a talking tree, Rosie gets turned into the nicest girl in the Dream Zone. | LineColor = 0000A0 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 9 | Title = I Was a Teenage Babysitter | OriginalAirDate = {{start date|1990|10|27|df=y}} | ShortSummary = Rosie must take care of the Greystone Giant's little son Rocky. | LineColor = 0000A0 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 10 | Title = The Wishing Whale | OriginalAirDate = {{start date|1990|11|3|df=y}} | ShortSummary = The Midnight Patrol (minus Keiko) meet the Wishing Whale who grants them their fondest wishes. But then the wishes get somewhat out of hand. | LineColor = 0000A0 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 11 | Title = Santa-Napped | OriginalAirDate = {{start date|1990|11|10|df=y}} | ShortSummary = The Nightmare Prince captures [[Santa Claus]], and the Midnight Patrol must rescue him to save [[Christmas]]. | LineColor = 0000A0 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 12 | Title = Save the Cave | OriginalAirDate = {{start date|1990|11|17|df=y}} | ShortSummary = The Greystone Giant is too far behind in his dream supplies, so the Midnight Patrol help him keep up with the dream orders. Though the Nightmare Prince plans to disrupt their plans. | LineColor = 0000A0 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 13 | Title = Rosie's Fuss Attack | OriginalAirDate = {{start date|1990|11|24|df=y}} | ShortSummary = Rosie changes form every time she complains, so the Midnight Patrol must find a special cure for her. | LineColor = 0000A0 }} |} ==Cast== * [[Charlie Adler|Charles Adler]] - Rocky (in "I Was a Teenage Babysitter") * Christine Avila - * [[Michael Bell (actor)|Michael Bell]] - Sebastian * [[Hamilton Camp]] - The Grand Dozer * [[Brian Cummings]] - * [[Jim Cummings]] - Giant Cat (in "King Potsworth"), Rags (in "King Potsworth") * [[Judyann Elder]] - * [[Pat Fraley|Patrick Fraley]] - Jester Dog (in "King Potsworth") * [[Richard Gautier|Dick Gautier]] - * [[Joan Gerber]] - Nightmare Prince's Mother * [[Dorian Harewood]] - * [[Elisabeth Harnois]] - Rosie * [[Whitby Hertford]] - Nick * [[Janice Kawaye]] - Keiko * [[Emily Kuroda]] - * George Lemore - Carter * [[David Lander]] - * [[Marilyn Lightstone]] - * [[Allan Lurie]] - * [[Kenneth Mars]] - Greystone Giant * [[Scott Menville]] - Wonder Kid (in "Nick's Super Switch") * [[Brian Stokes Mitchell|Brian Mitchell]] - * [[Howard Morris|Howie Morris]] - Dr. Akenhoffer (in "Rosie's Fuss Attack") * [[Ron Palillo]] - * [[Rob Paulsen]] - Nightmare Prince * [[Henry Polic II]] - * [[Clive Revill]] - Potsworth * [[Ronnie Schell]] - * Tom Scott - * [[Hal Smith (actor)|Hal Smith]] - * [[B. J. Ward (actress)|B.J. Ward]] - * [[Frank Welker]] - Murphy, Nosey Bird * Anderson Wong - ==Ratings (CBBC Channel)== :Monday 6th May 2002- 20,000 (9th most watched on CBBC that week) http://www.barb.co.uk ==Home Media release== In 1991, [[Hanna-Barbera|Hanna-Barbera Home Video]] released a single VHS cassette of the series in the United States entitled ''Potsworth and the Midnight Patrol'' containing four episodes which are "Save the Cave", "The Wishing Whale", "King Potsworth", and "The Nightmirror". ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|0281480|Potsworth & Co.}} * [http://www.toonarific.com/show.php?show_id=2381 Toonrific] {{The Funtastic World of Hanna-Barbera}} {{Dandy |state=collapsed}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Midnight Patrol: Adventures In The Dream Zone}} revision.text:
[[File:Millenial whoop.png|thumb|right|G - E - G figure]]
The '''millennial whoop''' is a melodic pattern alternating between the fifth and third notes in a [[major scale]], typically starting on the fifth, in the rhythm of straight 8th-notes, and often using the "wa" and "oh" syllables.<ref name="tp-20160820"/> It has been used extensively in 2010s [[pop music]].<ref name="guardian">{{Cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/shortcuts/2016/aug/30/millennial-whoop-pop-music|title=The Millennial Whoop: the melodic hook that’s taken over pop music |last=Haynes |first=Gavin |date=August 30, 2016 |website=The Guardian}}</ref><ref name="usatoday">{{Cite web |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/entertainthis/2016/08/29/what-millennial-whoop-and-why-every-pop-song/89547506/ |title=What is the 'millennial whoop' and why is it in every pop song? |last=Bui |first=Hoai-Tran |date=August 29, 2016 |website=USA Today}}</ref>
==Overview == {{Quote box |quote = In the slavishly playlisted, gnat's-attention-span world of daytime radio, the Whoop has become a signalling device, often cropping up bang on cue around the one-minute mark, saying: "Hey wait! Don't run away just yet!" |source = —Music blogger Patrick Metzger<ref name="guardian"/> |width = 25% }} The term was coined by the musician Patrick Metzger, who described it in a blog entry on ''The Patterning'' in August 2016.<ref name="tp-20160820"/> He suggested that, while the millennial whoop gained popularity from the late 2000s to 2010s, it has probably always been around.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bartleet|first1=Larry|title=What Is The Millennial Whoop? Once You Hear This Virulent Pop Hook You Won’t Be Able To Unhear It|url=http://www.nme.com/blogs/nme-blogs/what-is-the-millennial-whoop-songs|accessdate=3 September 2016|work=NME|date=September 1, 2016|ref=bartleet}}</ref> An earlier use can be heard in the 1983 song "[[Jungle Love (The Time song)|Jungle Love]]" by [[Morris Day and the Time]].<ref name="qz"/>
The 2017 song "Millennial Whoop" by American rock band [[The Pilgrims (band)|the Pilgrims]] was written as a response to the idea of older generations looking down upon the younger for using such tropes: the song makes use of the interval pattern.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://countytracks.com/2017/06/the-best-vermont-music-of-2017-so-far/|title=The Best Vermont Music of 2017 (So Far) - County Tracks|date=2017-06-22|work=County Tracks|access-date=2017-10-23|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Lawsuit == In 2013 songwriter [[Ally Burnett]] tried to sue Carly-Rae Jepsen and Owl City over their 2012 song "[[Good Time (Owl City and Carly Rae Jepsen song)|Good Time]]", arguing similarities to her 2010 song "Ah, It's a Love Song" and its use of the Millennial whoop.<ref name=guardian/> Jepsen settled out of court, but Owl City won.<ref name=guardian/>
== Uses == One notable use of the millennial whoop is in the 1987 theme song by [[Mark Mueller]] for the American animated television series ''[[DuckTales]]'' which ran for a total of 100 episodes.<ref name="ns-20171104"/> It does not occur in some other language versions of the 1987 theme<ref name="ns-20171104"/> nor in the 2017 English version of the theme song.<ref name="dxd-20170615"/>
Songs where the millennial whoop appear include: * "[[Jungle Love (The Time song)|Jungle Love]]" (1983, [[Morris Day and the Time]])<ref name="qz"/> * "[[Tarzan Boy]]" (1985, [[Baltimora]])<ref name="tp-20160820"/> (The B-part of the ABAB-structured chorus) * "[[In the Shadows (song)|In the Shadows]]" (2003, [[The Rasmus]])<ref name="tp-20160820"/><ref name="guardian"/> * "[[California Gurls]]" (2010, [[Katy Perry]])<ref name="qz"/> * "[[Good Time (Owl City and Carly Rae Jepsen song)|Good Time]]" (2012, [[Carly Rae Jepsen]] and [[Owl City]])<ref name=guardian/> * "[[Habits (Stay High)]]" (2013, [[Tove Lo]])<ref name="tp-20160820"/>
== See also == * [[Nyah nyah nyah nyah nyah nyah]] * [[Overtone series]]
==References== <references> <ref name="tp-20160820">{{Cite web|url=https://thepatterning.com/2016/08/20/the-millennial-whoop-a-glorious-obsession-with-the-melodic-alternation-between-the-fifth-and-the-third/|title=The Millennial Whoop: A glorious obsession with the melodic alternation between the fifth and the third|last=Metzger|first=Patrick|date=August 20, 2016|website=The Patterning|access-date=2016-09-19}}</ref> <ref name="qz">{{Cite web |url=https://qz.com/767812/millennial-whoop/ |title="The Millennial Whoop": The same annoying whooping sound is showing up in every popular song |last=Epstein |first=Adam |date=August 27, 2016 |website=Quartz}}</ref> <ref name="ns-20171104">NerdSync. "[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2lQVG7Gf7I4 Why the DUCKTALES Theme Song is Stuck in Your Head Right Now...]", YouTube. 4 November 2017. Retrieved 23 December 2017.</ref> <ref name="dxd-20170615">Disney XD. "[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YKSU82afy1w Theme Song DuckTales]", YouTube, 15 June 2017. Retrieved 23 December 2017.</ref> </references>
== External links == * [https://thepatterning.com/2016/08/20/the-millennial-whoop-a-glorious-obsession-with-the-melodic-alternation-between-the-fifth-and-the-third/ Original blog entry on thepatterning.com] * {{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fTvwM6S9vxI|title=Why do so many pop songs sound the same?|last=Metzger|first=Patrick|date=February 28, 2017|website=YouTube|access-date=2017-11-14}}
{{Pop music}}
[[Category:Pop music]] [[Category:2010s in music]] [[Category:Musical terminology]] [[Category:Words coined in the 2010s]]
{{music-stub}}

Founded in 1996 by [[World Fantasy Award]] winning editor [[Jeanne Cavelos]], the '''Odyssey Writing Workshop''' is held annually on the campus of [[Saint Anselm College]] in [[Goffstown, New Hampshire]].
== Notable graduates == *[http://www.juliettecrane.com Juliette Crane], Class of 2008 *[[Sara King]], Class of 2008 <ref>[http://www.sff.net/odyssey/grads08.html]</ref> *[[Carl Frederick]], Class of 2000 *[[Theodora Goss]], Class of 2000 * [[David J. Schwartz (science fiction writer)|David J. Schwartz]], Class of 1996 *[[Carrie Vaughn]], Class of 1998
==See also== * [[Terry Bisson]] * [[Ben Bova]] * [[Terry Brooks]] * [[John Crowley]] * [[Ellen Datlow]] * [[Charles de Lint]] * [[Harlan Ellison]] * [[Elizabeth Hand]] * [[George R. R. Martin]] * [[Patricia A. McKillip]] * [[Robert J. Sawyer]] * [[Nina Kiriki Hoffman]] * [[Dan Simmons]] * [[Jane Yolen]] * [[Center for the Study of Science Fiction]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.sff.net/odyssey/ Official Odyssey website] * {{Official website|http://www.jeannecavelos.com|Jeanne Cavelos official website}} * [http://www.sff.net/odyssey/schwartz.htm "Workshopping at Odyssey"] article by David J. Schwartz, graduate of the class of '96
{{SpecFicWorkshops}}
